title: What Is a Computer Network?
note: This section provides a fundamental definition of a computer network as a set of interconnected computers and devices that can share resources (like printers) and data. It explains the core purpose of networking, which is to enable communication and collaboration.

title: Network Types by Scale: LAN, MAN, and WAN
note: This lesson categorizes networks based on their geographical size. It defines a Local Area Network (LAN) for a small area like a home or office, a Metropolitan Area Network (MAN) for a city, and a Wide Area Network (WAN) for a large geographical area, with the Internet being the largest WAN.

title: Network Topologies
note: This section explains the concept of network topology as the arrangement of the elements (links, nodes, etc.) of a communication network. It covers the main physical topologies: Bus, Star (the most common in modern LANs), Ring, and Mesh.

title: The Concept of Layered Architecture
note: This lesson introduces the principle of a layered architecture in networking. It explains that the complex task of networking is broken down into smaller, more manageable parts called layers. Each layer provides a specific service to the layer above it and is responsible for a distinct set of tasks, promoting modularity and interoperability.

title: The OSI and TCP/IP Models
note: This section introduces the two primary reference models for networking. The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a 7-layer conceptual model. The TCP/IP model is a 4 or 5-layer model that is the practical basis for the modern Internet. The layers of each model are listed and their purposes are briefly described.

title: Encapsulation and Decapsulation
note: This lesson explains the process of data encapsulation. As data passes down through the layers of a sending host, each layer adds its own header (and sometimes a trailer) containing control information. This process is reversed at the receiving host (decapsulation) as the data moves up the layers.

title: Layer 1: The Physical Layer
note: This section details the role of the Physical Layer, which is responsible for the actual transmission of raw bits over a physical medium. It deals with the physical characteristics of the medium, such as the type of cable (e.g., twisted-pair, fiber optic) and the voltage levels for 0s and 1s.

title: Layer 2: The Data Link Layer
note: This lesson explains the role of the Data Link Layer, which is to provide reliable, node-to-node data transfer. Its main responsibilities are 'framing' (grouping bits into frames), physical addressing using MAC addresses, and error detection to identify corrupted frames.

title: MAC Addresses and Ethernet
note: This section introduces the Media Access Control (MAC) address as a unique, hard-coded address for a network interface card (NIC). It explains how MAC addresses are used for communication within a single local network (LAN). Ethernet is presented as the dominant Data Link Layer technology for wired LANs.

title: Network Switches
note: This lesson explains the function of a network switch, a key Data Link Layer device. Unlike a hub (a Physical Layer device that broadcasts data to all ports), a switch intelligently forwards frames only to the specific port connected to the destination MAC address, improving efficiency and reducing collisions.

title: Wireless LANs (Wi-Fi)
note: This lesson introduces wireless networking. It covers the IEEE 802.11 family of standards (Wi-Fi), explaining concepts like SSIDs for network identification, channels, and the CSMA/CA access method. It also discusses wireless security protocols like WPA2 and WPA3.

title: Layer 3: The Network Layer
note: This section details the role of the Network Layer, which is responsible for the source-to-destination delivery of packets across multiple networks. Its two main functions are logical addressing (using IP addresses) and routing (determining the best path for packets to travel).

title: The Internet Protocol (IP) and IPv4 Addresses
note: This lesson introduces the Internet Protocol (IP) as the primary protocol of the Network Layer. It focuses on the structure of an IPv4 address (a 32-bit number) and explains how it provides a unique logical address. The concepts of address classes and subnet masks are also introduced.

title: The Challenge of IPv4 and Introduction to IPv6
note: This lesson discusses the problem of IPv4 address exhaustion. It then introduces IPv6 as the solution, explaining its 128-bit address space, its hexadecimal notation, and the simplification of the header compared to IPv4. The long-term importance of transitioning to IPv6 is emphasized.

title: Routers: The Workhorses of the Internet
note: This section explains the function of a router, the primary Network Layer device. A router connects different networks together and uses routing tables and routing protocols (like RIP, OSPF, and BGP) to make decisions about forwarding packets toward their final destination.

title: Network Address Translation (NAT)
note: This lesson explains NAT, a ubiquitous technology used in home and corporate networks. It describes how NAT allows multiple devices with private, non-routable IP addresses to share a single public IP address, conserving the limited supply of IPv4 addresses.

title: Layer 4: The Transport Layer
note: This lesson explains the role of the Transport Layer, which provides logical communication between processes running on different hosts. It introduces the concept of port numbers, which are used to identify the specific application process that data is intended for on a destination machine.

title: The User Datagram Protocol (UDP)
note: This section covers UDP, a simple, connectionless Transport Layer protocol. UDP provides a best-effort delivery service with no reliability, flow control, or error correction. It is fast and suitable for applications where speed is more important than reliability, such as video streaming or online gaming.

title: The Transmission Control Protocol (TCP)
note: This lesson details TCP, a reliable, connection-oriented protocol that forms the backbone of most internet communication. It explains its key features, including the three-way handshake to establish a connection, sequence numbers to ensure ordered delivery, and acknowledgements to guarantee reliability.

title: TCP Flow and Congestion Control
note: This section dives deeper into TCP's reliability features. It explains Flow Control, which prevents a fast sender from overwhelming a slow receiver, and Congestion Control, which helps the network as a whole prevent and recover from traffic overload.

title: Layer 5: The Application Layer
note: This section covers the Application Layer, the top layer of the network model. This is the layer that user applications interact with. It provides the protocols that enable software to send and receive information and present meaningful data to users.

title: The Domain Name System (DNS)
note: This lesson explains DNS as the 'phonebook of the Internet'. It is a distributed database system that translates human-readable domain names (like `www.google.com`) into machine-readable IP addresses (like `172.217.10.142`), which are required for locating computer services and devices worldwide.

title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
note: This lesson explains how DHCP automates the process of assigning IP addresses to devices on a network. It covers the DORA (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge) process, which allows a device to join a network and get an IP address, subnet mask, and default gateway without manual configuration.

title: The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
note: This section introduces HTTP as the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web. It explains the request-response model, where a client (like a web browser) sends an HTTP request to a server, which then returns an HTTP response containing the requested resource (like an HTML page).

title: Email Protocols (SMTP, POP3, IMAP)
note: This lesson covers the suite of protocols that handle email. It explains the role of SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) for sending email, and contrasts the two main protocols for receiving email: POP3 (which downloads mail) and IMAP (which synchronizes mail with the server).

title: File Transfer Protocols (FTP and SFTP)
note: This lesson introduces protocols designed for transferring files between computers. It explains the original File Transfer Protocol (FTP) and its use of separate control and data connections. It then introduces SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol) as the modern, secure alternative that performs file transfers over an encrypted channel.

title: Basic Network Troubleshooting Tools
note: This lesson introduces essential command-line tools for diagnosing network problems. It covers 'ping' for testing reachability and latency, 'traceroute' (or 'tracert') for tracing the path a packet takes across the network, and 'ipconfig' (or 'ifconfig') for viewing a host's own IP configuration.

title: Network Security: Firewalls and VPNs
note: This final lesson provides an overview of key network security technologies. It explains how Firewalls act as a barrier to filter malicious traffic. It also introduces Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) as a technology to create a secure, encrypted connection (a 'tunnel') over a less secure network, such as the public internet.
